Now, she puts it into drawings. Under her bed, she had sketchbooks and sketchbooks of her as a blueberry or about to become a blueberry. "I...I..." Veruca was staring down at the drawing in her hands. She shook her head, "I thought I was the only one who did this..." She said with a whisper.

Violet blinked a few times, confused, "What?"

Veruca set Violet's sketchbook down, and turned to her own bag. She pulled out a tattered old composition notebook, clearly worn from use. Inside were pages upon pages of drawings, each one of her in a different situation of becoming a blueberry. She handed it to Violet, who took it with a shaking hand.

"I thought I'd never get to share this secret with anyone." Veruca admits.

"Wow..." Violet looked over the drawings one by one. Some were simply test drawings, but others were full scenes, each of Veruca swelling up like a blueberry, just as Violet had wanted. "These are really good." She said with a smile.

Sitting proudly at his brand new desk, Charlie Bucket gazed over several dozen sheets of official business documents given to him from Wonka as part of his initial assignments. From the catwalks above, Charlie peered down with awe and disdain, the massive cakewoman waving towards him as her body was pinched and prodded with mechanical claws. "Before...?" she paused, a look of mild pain scrunched across her face. "H-honestly, I keep hearing echoy voices telling me funny stuff about being a champion or that I'm the best. Sometimes, I even have these weird visions of being someplace completely foreign, people cheering someone's name. And the weirdest part is I think they're cheering for me."

"V-very interesting Ms. Sangria. Have you addressed this with anyone else?"

"Mr. Wonka said it's all part of my process of adjusting. All I have to do is eat a candy pill every day and he said they'll make the weird stuff go away.That way, I can focus on my job."

"...I'm not sure. they oddly feel a part of mean, but not at the same time. It's all so very confusing..."

"I could imagine. Perhaps holding back on the pills for now might be best, just to be safe. I'll schedule for counseling in the evenings to see if we can't absolve this issue."

Still embedded into her horny fantasy, Scarlett barely acknowledged Violet's presence, groaning loudly for more. Violet, with much trepidation, slowly drew upon the growing sphere of her mother, sniffing at the air.

"Blueberries...oh no..." she croaked, fingers trembling just above the blue flesh before her. The dreams, they began to flash back into her mind, the visions of her being overinflated, skin slightly creaking tot he touch as she was rubbed and played with like a human balloon. 1221.content:
"A blueberry? Really Mr. Wonka? You surely are over exaggerating!" exclaimed Scarlette as a bemused look filled her face. The eccentric inventor had been inhaling the fumes from his many machines, which had somehow taken its toll on the poor man's face. "Are you sure you're not just making up another weird story?"

"I assure you m'aam I'm not," defended Wonka, "I would never joke or fabricate someone turning into a blueberry. It's just too weird to make up."

An annoying laugh escaped her throat that sounded a cross between a donkey and sorority girl drunk laugh. She looked around the room, searching for some backup from the other skeptical tour members. No one joined her, the embarrassment following the awkward situation brought her laughing fit to a premature end. "Mr. Wonka it's impossible for people to turn into fruit. After all, if it were possible , surely the medical world would have seen at least one instance. Your mind must be playing tricks on you."

"Oh my mind does play tricks on me, quite often in fact," he said with a child like smile at the though of the wacky sights that had filled his mind during the mad episodes. Some of his best work had originated from these "trippy" spells that had spurred the inventor to push the boundaries of known candy creations. "However, I know that the sights of little girls and oompa loompas expanding into a blueberry were surely real and not a figment of my reality."

"Uh huh," Scarlette said skeptically as she cocked an eyebrow up, one of her hidden and unattractive talents, as she showed her skepticism to the what appeared to be the mindless rants of a lunatic, who flashed another eerie grin at her. "Mr. Wonka is this just some odd way of saying their tongues turned blue, or they had bad blueberry breath, because I'm still just not buying that you're actually telling the truth."

Wonka's face filled with a sad and frustrated smile, how was he not getting through to this woman. What was hard to understand about the phrase, swelling into a blueberry. Was she stupid? Had he lied to her in the past to make her doubt him? Did the marvelous creations he had made not justify his ability to defy the impossible? He didn't know. "Umm, Ms. Beauregarde..."

"Mrs. Beauregarde," corrected the lovely blonde, whose patience was starting to wane.

"Excuse me, Mrs. Beauregarde, I assure you that I'm not quite certain how I'm confusing you?"

"YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND!" Violet's mother cried out in shock. "How do you not understand how odd and unconvincing the phrase turning into a blueberry is?" She walked over to the machine and grabbed the strip of gum hanging from the exotic looking machine. "You are honestly telling me that this little piece of gum, this simple candy, has the side effect of making a person blow up iin to a blueberry? The notion of such an act happening is absurd because people don't swell into fruit. They might have an allergic reaction where they get puffy sure, but nobody I know has ever come close to changing into a blueberry." She spat at the last word as if his descriptive term was a tainted taste that had poisoned her tongue.

"Well as you discovered today... there are many things you haven't seen that exist. So surely that is proof enough that such a concept is not impossible."

"Making tricks and treats is one trick Wonka, and sculpting food into shapes is not something that hasn't been seen before, or do you not see the numerous television shows that focus on those artists."

"I don't really watch TV, it destroys the imagination and rots the mind!"

"Hey!" cried out Mike Teevee.

"See my point," said Wonka.

A few giggles escaped the other tourists, Veruca, Violet and Scarlette in particular as the three girls' feministic attitudes relished any quips thrown at the opposite sex. "Do you all really believe what this man is saying?" asked Scarlett with shock and surprise as she turned in a circle to look at the crowd. She held her arm straight out, the gum wedged between her thumb and index finger, as she looked for any aid in her argument. Many of the parents remained silent, most refusing to meet her eyes as they stared at the small stick in her hands, their eyes portraying fear at the sight of such a small and benign piece of candy. Apparently Wonka's story had breached their rationality, overriding it with ridiculous tales and ideas of an irrational punishment.

"Nobody hear agrees with me, with how stupid this sounds?"

"I do mother," said Violet, her little prodigy smiling with the confidence Scarlet had beaten into her daughter. Scarlett had worked hard to make sure Violet was succesful and surely she would be an elite member of society, crushing the competition in whatever endeavors she chose to pursue.

"Thank you honey, I knew I could count on you," she said with a smirk as she gazed back at her fellow tour members. "Unlike the rest of the cowards that seem to be in this group." Scarlett passed another glare at the audience before returning her attention to Wonka. "They're just too chicken to speak up , but the truth is Wonka, no one here believes in this blueberry mumbo jumbo."

"Heh, Heh, Heh... Mumbo Jumbo, that's funny."

"What is?" Scarlett asked with confusion.

"The word Mumbo Jumbo, it sounds funny... and really weird."

"Oh for lord's sake, have you been smoking something Mr. Wonka. Honestly first the stupid blueberry story and now you're laughing at a word. What's next, are we all going to magically lift off the ground and fly towards the ceiling?"

"Oh not at all, unless you tried my fizzy lifting drinks, they can make people lighter than air due to the constant carbonation, another side effect I haven't quite figured out yet."

"Oh for crying out loud," Scarlett yelled in frustration. This eccentric game of cat and mouse phrases was really getting on her nerves and it was no longer funny to her. "Mr. Wonka, I'm sick of your lying! Tell the truth, you just don't want to give up the gum, because of how expensive it is to make. This blueberry story is nothing but a scam!!!!!"

"I promise you I did not lie, those who chewed it really did...."

"Turn into blueberries," she rudely interrupted. "If that's true, then show me some proof. Where are these so called blueberry people?"

"Well I couldn't leave them that way. If i did they could have exploded, so we juiced them."

"Juiced them? With what another ingenious gum?"

"Oh no, we have a juicing room. It's state of the art and..."

"When will you stop lying you strange man?" asked Scarlett as she shook her head. An annoyed smirk crossed her lips, and she just stared at him with a look that was part pity and anger.

"I don't think he is lying," said Charlie Buckett, the quiet English boy who was forced to live in poverty conditions. Scarlett shot a look towards him, another annoyance filling her face at his audacity.

"Sorry little boy, but I don't believe in fairy tales." Scarlett squinted her eyes just enough to make herself look threatening.

"But it's not a fairy tale," assured Mr. Wonka who had finally reached his limits of the round and round discussion. "If you don't believe than by all means try it yourself."

The offer had surprised Scarlett, her theory about not wanting to waste the gum seemed to have gone out the window. Her eyes darted back towards the inventor and stared at him for a long time, an attempt to read through his deception. There was none though, at least none on his face, as he just smiled back at her with that innocent grin. What was he getting at? She looked at the gum strip and pondered the question once more. Was Wonka telling the truth? Did this gum really have the power to turn someone into a blueberry? It was frightening to her.

She passed another glance towards Wonka and looked at his creepy smile once more. No, no it had to be a lie, this was just another game to him, an attempt to show off his bravery and test her own courage to a challenge.

"What did you say?" she asked in an air-headed manner, a noble attempt to buy her some more time to think about the challenge.

"I said if you don't believe me try it yourself!"

Scarlett was still confused, but she tried not to show the uncertainty and fear she was feeling. An arrogant smile filled her face as she tried to face her challenger with the confident image she had prided herself in. Surely he was thinking she would back at now, but she was pushing this challenge to the limits, calling his bluff of the blueberry story. Yet his face didn't change, except to a little more uncertain as he wondered what she was going to do. His calmness was both bold and scary. A new fear welled up inside her and she wasn't certain as to what course she should take, nor what theory was true about the gum.

She stole a look at Violet, her daughter now looking at her wide eyed with admiration and wonder at the woman who was her mother. Flashbacks of all the lessons she had taught her daughter in training rushed back and she knew the words of Never back down from a challenge, always go for the gold and the win, were embedded in her offspring's mind. To go back on that saying, that teaching, would surely make her daughter lose respect for her mother. It was something she couldn't do, nor live with for the rest of her life.

Her faith restored, Scarlett's doubts melted away and her arrogant smile grew wider as she looked back at their tour guide.

"My dear woman, I wouldn't do that," warned Grandpa Joe, the old fool that was with the poor boy. The senile geezer was annoying her, "Why is that?"

"Because Mr. Wonka's kind soul would never lie or make up a story. I know from working with him!"

"Uh huh, whatever," she said as she looked back at the gum. She stared back at the gum and realized that it was now or never. What would she do? Scarlett

12211.content:
Scarlett looked from the gum down to her daughter, an act of desperation to calm her last minute doubts over what she would do. The aspiring hope in her daughter's eyes mirrored the pride she had for her family. To not follow the morals she had taught Violet, would bring shame and embarrassment to herself and Violet would most likely never respect her again. Losing that respect was something Scarlett refused to live with. Reassuring Violet with her arrogant grin, Scarlett returned to Wonka and said, "I'm a Beauregarde and we don't back down from challenges." With one last glance, Scarlett threw caution to the wind and popped the gum into her mouth, her jaw muscles reflexing to the stimulus as they mindlessly began to chew.

No one spoke as the foolish woman began to work the gum in her mouth, her cocky stare directed towards Wonka as she mocked his pathetic attempt to scare her. She couldn't believe she had nearly chickened out, or even worse, believed his ridiculous tale of transformation into a fruit. As she continued to enjoy the gum, she looked on to the crowd who stared at her waiting for something to happen. Some of them had looks of terror on their face, their bodies still as they held their breath at the punishment to supposedly befall her. Others looked at her with wonder, perhaps even fascination as she chewed, almost as if they wanted ill-fortune to fall on her; how sick their minds must have been.

"How is it Mom?" asked Violet, the curiosity in her voice revealing what she thought was her daughter's biggest weakness. The saying curiosity killed the cat, described her Violet well, her innate nature of wanting to know about everything had led to the few failures in her young daughter's life. Scarlett tried to forget Violet's past losses by focusing on the present, which at the moment was chewing gum.

"Well to tell you the truth it's rather bland, and kind of tasteless," she responded as her jaws continued to work against the stubborn candy. The ignorant mother just looked back at Wonka, her eyes going from smug enjoyment to smug confusion. "What gives Wonka? Was this just an attempt to test your contestant's courage, or were you trying to cover up the scam of this tasteless gum?"

"Neither I believe, as I don't usually have this type of humor, but maybe. I wonder what's different about that piece?" He grabbed a card and began to look over the information for the particular batch, trying to point out any differences from the prescribed formula. His eyebrows curled in confusion at the lack of answers and he looked back up at the scornful woman.

"Maybe it's just a bad piece," suggest Charlie.

"Or perhaps it just takes a while to work up its flavor," said Mr. Teevee.

"If anything the old girl's taste buds have probably been destroyed from all the jobs she's given her husband," said Mr. Salt with a laugh.

That answer got a hate filled look from Scarlett, her eyes shooting invisible daggers towards the pompous English man. He buttoned up, knowing not to unleash the wrath of a woman's scorn. Despite her Jersey Girl chewing style, Mrs. Beauregarde's look was enough to make Mr. Salt sweat, forcing him to loosen his collar to vent the heat from beneath.

Seeing him sweat forced a wicked smile on her face and she continued to stare at him to drive the fear of her power into his mind.

"See, Mr. Wonka, I knew you were full of crock with that story. Just admit it, you were only lying about the wonderful miracle gum."

"I did not lie, but fortunately for you the prototype's failure was in your favor."

"Yeah sure," Scarlett scoffed as she flashed her confident smile at the tour once more, the toothy grin constantly interrupted with her chewing.

Wonka looked back with one last look of uncertainty before he walked towards the exit. "Should we get on with the tour then?" he asked with a slight whimper in his voice, obviously frustrated with Scarlett's smug victory.

"Sounds like a good idea sir," replied Charlie.

"Where you go, I will follow you always sir," replied Grandpa Joe.

"Yeah whatever," said Mike.

"A Beauregarde is ready for any challenge," Violet screamed out eagerly. "Especially when it comes to gum! Right mom?"

"That's right honey, particularly gum that tastes..." she paused, something was happening, something she didn't expect.

"That tastes like what mom... bland?" Violet asked trying to finish the sentence.

"No, no it's not bland anymore," Scarlett said as her chewing slightly picked up pace, trying to determine what the change was. This taste was familiar, the texture rich and creamy, yet like liquid as it rushed over her tongue, something that also tasted...warm? "Unbelievable," she screamed with now wide eyes, the cockiness essentially gone when seconds ago she was beaming with overconfidence and arrogance. Now though, it was wonder and excitement, as she realized the taste...TOMATO SOUP just like her mother used to make when she was sick.

"What's unbelievable?" asked Veruca, the brat obviously jealous from the amazing taste sensation going on in her mouth.

"Mr. Wonka, this doesn't taste like blueberries, but like tomato soup. This is incredible, it's like I'm actually eating it," she was now close to shouting, her amazement getting the best of her as her smile started to evolve from smug to one of sheer enjoyment. "It feels hot and creamy, and almost like it is running down my throat."

No one spoke, their eyes darting from Wonka to Scarlett, as they were unsure what to do.

"I told you it was amazing, didn't I, DIDN'T I?" he said with excitement as his volume increased. Someone finally recognized his true genius, a real adult who could look past his odd visions and see the treasure beneath. He brought out a notebook from his pocket and started to scribble some notes about his observations, eagerly awaiting to hear more.

"Mr. Wonka, how did you do this, it tastes so good!" she cried

"A magician never reveals his secrets, and so too does this magician.

"I thought you were an inventor?" asked Mike.

"Same thing in my mind little mumbling man."

Scarlett said nothing, she was too captivated by the tomato soup flavor, which now seemed to be fading, as if she was finishing the meal. "Hey it's going away! What's happening to the tomato soup Mr. Wonka?"

"You're finishing the first course. It is a three course meal Mrs. Beauregarde. One course finishes and another begins, otherwise it would only be a one course meal and that would just be weird. Though if I were you Ms. Beauregarde, I would really stop chewing and spit the gum out."
